text: [Music]
Well, I I actually think the
digitalization of the world or the
digital title wave
uh that's sweeping through the world is
touching every kind of industry and walk
of life. I don't care if you're a a
preschool teacher, a parish priest, the
CEO of General Motors, or a newspaper
publisher, editor. it's touching your
life. Uh uh the media companies whether
it's entertainment or information have
been especially hard hit because uh by
the change because uh the internet is a
great uh uh platform for media. It
really, if you think about it, despite
all the hype about video on the internet
and the fact that the these videos will
be on the internet, it is still today as
we speak in September of 2007
overwhelmingly a text medium.
Overwhelmingly a text medium. And so
it's a direct competitor for newspapers
and
magazines. And newspapers and magazines
have not been the best managed
companies, no matter how good their
journalism is. and they've not
necessarily been the most uh uh
entrepreneurial and flexible companies,
but they've been hard hit. Uh I don't
believe journalism as we know it is
going away at all. In fact, I think all
the evidence is it's booming and
expanding. But journalism as done only
by a small group of professional
journalists and only on
uh uh dead trees or only on you know
official television networks. That kind
of journalism is being is being uh
radically radically transformed and and
challenged by uh journalism carried on
the internet. But it's still journalism.
[Music]
